awd_titl_txt: The Structure of the Gromov-Witten Invariants
awd_abstract_narration:
Objects known as symplectic manifolds are of fundamental importance in the study of modern geometry and physics. This award supports research that lies at the intersection of symplectic geometry, which provides the framework for classical mechanics, and string theory, which developed as a potential candidate for unifying general relativity and particle physics, enabling the study of models of space-time and phase-spaces inaccessible by other means. The problems considered are deep and of foundational nature, and answers to these will lead to new techniques and interactions among different fields of mathematics and will have potential applications in string theory. There are many interesting applications of this work, and many of the promising directions for continuing this line of research, involve students. The research and outreach activities of the principal investigator will have an impact on the education of next generation of mathematicians, engaging them in cutting-edge research early in their graduate career.
 
The theme of this research involves symplectic manifolds and the structure of the invariants associated to them. Specifically, one of the projects aims to understand the geometric reasons behind a general type structure theorem for many flavors of Gromov-Witten invariants. These types of structures were conjectured using string theory and have spurred a lot of interest in mathematics and many attempts to understand the geometry behind them. A second project aims to understand the properties of the Gromov-Witten virtual fundamental cycle in symplectic geometry and explore its functorial aspects. It includes a proposed set of axioms that would uniquely determine it, inspired by the Eilenberg-Steenrod axioms for homology theories. There are many different constructions of the Gromov-Witten virtual fundamental class of closed symplectic manifolds, each one with its own strengths and advantages, so knowing that most of these constructions carry the same information is useful, allowing one to choose whatever construction may be best suited for the particular problem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this NSF grant involves the study of symplectic manifolds and more specifically explores the structure of the invariants associated to them. Symplectic manifolds are of fundamental importance in modern geometry and physics, and one way to understand them is by studying invariants such as the so called Gromov-Witten invariants, which involve counts of holomorphic curves. 


In a series of joint papers, the PI and her collaborators explored and proved several structural results for the Gromov-Witten invariants of 6-dimensional symplectic manifolds, and worked on generalizing them to the context of symplectic manifolds endowed with an anti-symplectic involution. The existence of these types of structures were originally conjectured by two theoretical physicists Gopakumar and Vafa using string theory heuristics and have spurred a lot of interest in mathematics and many attempts to understand the geometry behind them. In particular, in joint work with Penka Georgieva the PI determined a certain 2-dimensional Klein topological quantum field theory and used it to prove a local version of the Gopakumar-Vafa conjecture for symplectic manifolds with an anti-symplectic involution. 


Broader impacts: A significant part of the funding from this award was used to support the research of graduate students, contributing to the training and education of the next generation of mathematicians, and engaging them in cutting-edge research early in their graduate career. The PI has disseminated the work supported by this grant by giving numerous talks and participating in national and international level conferences and workshops. The PI also co-organized workshops, such as the MSRI workshop on New four-dimensional gauge theories, and served as the faculty mentor for the Kylerec Graduate Workshops in Symplectic and Contact Geometry, furthering the professional development of the graduate students and postdoctoral fellows which participated in them. The PI has also been active in encouraging and supporting broadening participation, diversity and inclusion in mathematics, and will continue to do so.


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: Eleny-Nicoleta Ionel
